statement.text: The critical care physician plays an essential role in mesenteric ischemia as the frontline provider for NOMI recognition in ICU patients, perioperative resuscitation, and long-term management of survivors; understanding the intensivist perspective enhances collaborative care and improves outcomes.
statement.formal: ICU Role: (1) NOMI recognition in at-risk patients (vasopressors, cardiac surgery, shock); (2) Resuscitation optimization; (3) Post-operative management after revascularization/resection; (4) Goals of care discussions; (5) Long-term rehabilitation

explanation.intuition: NOMI is predominantly an ICU problem—it occurs in critically ill patients who are already being managed by intensivists. The challenge is recognizing mesenteric ischemia in patients who may be sedated, intubated, and unable to report symptoms. Surgeons must understand this challenge and work collaboratively with ICU teams for early detection.
explanation.key_insight: The intensivist sees mesenteric ischemia from a different lens: as a complication of systemic illness, not a primary surgical problem. Prevention (optimizing perfusion, minimizing vasopressors), early recognition, and post-operative support are their primary contributions.
explanation.technical_details: ICU patients at highest risk for NOMI include those on high-dose vasopressors, post-cardiac surgery (especially CABG, valve), post-major aortic surgery, and those with cardiogenic or septic shock. Feeding intolerance, rising lactate, and unexplained acidosis are key warning signs.

clinical_monitoring: Daily abdominal exam (even in sedated patients—distension, tympany)

laboratory.lactate_trend: Most useful; single value less informative
laboratory.wbc_trend: Rising or falling WBC in context

imaging.threshold: Low threshold for CTA if NOMI suspected
imaging.limitation: CTA findings may be subtle in NOMI

prevention.minimize_vasopressors: Use lowest effective dose; consider alternative vasoactive agents
prevention.early_enteral_nutrition: Controversial in high-risk; may stimulate flow or stress gut

goals: Stabilize hemodynamics (if possible without excessive delay)
preoperative_resuscitation.reality: Often must proceed urgently; resuscitation continues intraoperatively

intraoperative_support.massive_transfusion_protocol: Have available for extensive necrosis cases

monitoring: Hemodynamic monitoring (arterial line, central line, consider PA catheter)
Trending lactate (should improve if revascularization successful)

resuscitation.blood_products: Correct coagulopathy; massive transfusion protocols if needed

anticoagulation.timing: Balance between thrombosis prevention and bleeding
anticoagulation.approach: Often start heparin 24-48h post-op if no active bleeding

nutrition.timing: Start enteral when gut function recovers
nutrition.tpn: If prolonged ileus or SBS anticipated

icu_role.facilitating_discussions: ICU team often leads goals of care discussions

when_to_consider_palliation: No realistic chance of meaningful recovery
Patient/family wishes align with comfort care

shared_decision_making.when: Early in course for high-risk or poor-prognosis cases

clinical_pearls.pearl: In sedated ICU patients, abdominal distension and feeding intolerance may be the only signs of developing mesenteric ischemia
clinical_pearls.implication: Have high vigilance for NOMI in at-risk populations

clinical_pearls.pearl: Rising lactate despite resuscitation in a patient on vasopressors should prompt consideration of mesenteric ischemia
clinical_pearls.implication: Don't attribute rising lactate only to the primary illness—consider NOMI

clinical_pearls.pearl: Post-cardiac surgery patients with unexplained acidosis or inability to wean vasopressors may have NOMI
clinical_pearls.implication: Low threshold for imaging in this population

clinical_pearls.pearl: The ICU team often knows the patient best—their input on prognosis and goals of care is essential before major surgery
clinical_pearls.implication: Engage ICU team in treatment decisions, especially for high-risk patients
